citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was one fennec fox with long nails. The fifth digit nail on both front limbs were so long that they extended outward.
Failure to trim nails can lead to overgrowth which can cause pain, injury, and/or gait abnormalities. Each exhibitor shall
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent,
control, and treat diseases and injuries.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility's only male Bengal cat was observed to have excessive drainage from the right eye. The hair at the corners
the eye was moist and thinning. The skin in these areas was also wet and reddened. The licensee had not identified the
eye issue. Failure to conduct thorough daily observations of all animals can lead to delayed diagnosis and treatment and
unnecessary animal discomfort. Daily observations of all animals to assess their health and well-being must be
conducted. Daily observations may be accomplished by someone other than the attending veterinarian provided there is a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health,
behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending veterinarian.

The licensee did not provide the microchip number for the male Bengal cat and did not produce a microchip reader for
inspectors to view the microchip number for the Bengal cat. There was no official USDA tag attached to the cat or kennel.
There was no record/documentation for the Bengal cat and no photograph of the Bengal cat.
All live cats used for exhibition must be identified to ensure animals can be traced and tracked in the case of animal
disease outbreak, and to specifically identify animals in need of veterinary care.
A class "C'' exhibitor shall identify all live dogs and cats under his or her control or on his or her premises, whether held,
purchased, or otherwise acquired. This can be accomplished by an official USDA sequentially numbered tag that is kept
on the door of the animal's cage or run, or by microchip with a microchip reader on hand. Cats used for exhibition must
also have a record or documentation which includes the tag number or microchip, a written description of the animal and
photograph.
To be corrected by November 16, 2023

There was one turkey outside its primary enclosure. Failure to keep birds within their enclosure can cause unnecessary
distress due to their lack of access to food, water, and shelter. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained
so that they contain the birds securely allowing them access to food, water, and shelter and to prevent attack by
predators.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have an environmental enrichment program for birds at that is approved by the attending veterinarian.
Failure to develop and document an environmental enrichment program for birds can negatively impact their health and
well-being, causing unnecessary psychological distress. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-
appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan
must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in subpart G and with
currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals and reference guides. This plan
must be made available to APHIS upon request. The plan must address each category listed in 3.154.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
JUSTINE O MALLEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was one fennec fox with long nails. The fifth digit nail on both front limbs were so long that they extended outward. 
Failure to trim nails can lead to overgrowth  which can cause pain, injury, and/or gait abnormalities. Each exhibitor shall 
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, and treat diseases and injuries. 
2.40(b)(3)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility's only male Bengal cat was observed to have excessive drainage from the right eye. The hair at the corners 
the eye was moist and thinning. The skin in these areas was also wet and reddened. The licensee had not identified the

2.50(c) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
The licensee did not provide  the microchip number for the male Bengal cat and did not produce a microchip reader for 
inspectors to view the microchip number for the Bengal cat. There was no official USDA tag attached to the cat or kennel. 
There was no record/documentation for the Bengal cat and no photograph of the Bengal cat. 
All live cats used for exhibition must be identified to ensure animals can be traced and tracked in the case of animal 
disease outbreak, and to specifically identify animals in need of veterinary care.  
A class "C'' exhibitor shall identify all live dogs and cats under his or her control or on his or her premises, whether held, 
purchased, or otherwise acquired. This can be accomplished by an official USDA sequentially numbered tag that is kept 
on the door of the animal's cage or run, or by microchip with a microchip reader on hand. Cats used for exhibition must 
also have a record or documentation which includes the tag number or microchip, a written description of the animal and 
photograph. 
To be corrected by November  16, 2023

3.153(a)(1)(iii)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
There was one turkey outside its primary enclosure. Failure to keep birds within their enclosure can cause unnecessary 
distress due to their lack of access to food, water, and shelter. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained 
so that they contain the birds securely allowing them access to food, water, and shelter and to prevent attack by 
predators. 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility did not have an environmental  enrichment program for birds at that is approved  by the attending veterinarian. 
Failure to develop  and document an environmental  enrichment program for birds can negatively impact their health and 
well-being, causing unnecessary psychological distress. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-
appropriate plan for environmental  enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan 
must be approved  by the attending veterinarian  and must be in accordance with the regulations in subpart G and with 
currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate  professional journals and reference guides. This plan 
must be made available  to APHIS upon request. The plan must address each category listed in 3.154. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
JUSTINE O MALLEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
KURT HAMMEL, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
